content: The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" allows for the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" permits the withdrawal of specified coal preference right lease applications, with the Secretary of the Interior issuing bidding rights certificates to the holders. The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" allows for the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications without further adjudication by the Secretary, with relinquishment of rights upon issuance of bidding rights certificates. The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" allows for withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications without further adjudication by the Secretary, with relinquishment of rights upon issuance of bidding rights certificates. Method for determining fair market value is outlined in Section 3. The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" allows for withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications without further adjudication by the Secretary. The fair market value of withdrawn coal reserves is determined by a panel established by the Secretary within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will establish a panel to determine the fair market value of coal reserves from withdrawn coal preference right lease applications under the Act. The panel will consist of 3 representatives appointed by the Secretary, the holder of the preference right lease application, and one additional representative. The Secretary will contract a mineral appraiser to determine the fair market value of a coal reserve. The panel may supplement information as needed. The panel will determine the fair market value of a coal reserve for any withdrawn coal preference right lease application within 75 days of establishment. SEC. 4. ISSUANCE OF PATENTS TO RELINQUISHED PREFERENCE RIGHT LEASE APPLICATIONS. The Secretary shall issue patents to the Navajo Nation for land, including mineral rights, within 120 days of withdrawing a coal preference right lease application, to satisfy the Navajo Nation's land selection rights in New Mexico. This aims to facilitate land consolidation. The Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for land and mineral rights within 120 days of withdrawing a coal preference right lease application to fulfill land selection rights in New Mexico. This is to aid land consolidation and mineral development in northwest New Mexico. The Secretary's duties in this regard are enforceable in a mandamus proceeding under section 1361 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 5. USE OF EXCHANGE BIDDING RIGHTS. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) can be transferred in whole or in part and constitutes a monetary credit that can be applied against certain obligations. The certificate of bidding rights can be applied against rentals, royalties, and bonus payments payable to the Secretary under Federal coal leases. The certificate of bidding rights issued under the Mineral Leasing Act can be used as a monetary credit against a payment obligation for a Federal coal lease. The holder can apply the bidding rights to 50% of the amount payable, with the remaining 50% to be paid in cash or cash equivalent as per the lease terms. The holder of a certificate of bidding rights under the Mineral Leasing Act can use it to cover 50% of a Federal coal lease payment, with the remaining 50% to be paid in cash or its equivalent as per the lease terms. Under the Mineral Leasing Act, 50% of the payment for a Federal coal lease can be made using a certificate of bidding rights, with the remaining 50% to be paid in cash. The payment made in cash is distributed to the State where the lease is located and treated as a redistribution under the Act. The payment made through crediting of bidding rights is subject to redistribution to the Reclamation and Miscellaneous Receipts accounts in the Treasury.
